awd_titl_txt: Travel to the XIXth International Congress on Mathematical Physics, July 23--28, 2018, Montreal, Canada, and to Related Events
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "The XIXth International Conference on Mathematical Physics" that will be held in Montreal, Canada, 2018 from June 23-28, 2018.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the field of mathematical physics.   A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference.  This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference.   The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities.   More information will be made available at:
https://icmp2018.org/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The International Congress in Mathematical Physics (ICMP) is held every three years to highlight state-of-the-art research at the boundary of mathematics and physics, sponsored by the International Association of Mathematical Physics. ICMP XIX was held in Montr ́eal from July 23–28, 2018, preceded by a Young Researchers Symposium (YRS) on July 20 and 21. ICMP XIX had almost 600 participants, YRS had 176 participants.

Part of the program consisted of sixteen plenary lectures (including by a Nobel Prize winner and a Fields Medal winner) and twelve thematic sessions. There were also opportunities for participants to present their recent work in contributed talks and a poster session. A broad range of areas of mathematical physics was represented, such as general relativity, quantum mechanics and quantum information, statistical mechanics, and string theory & quantum gravity. Among the mathematical methods used in these fields, particular attention was given to dynamical systems, partial differential equations, spectral theory, as well as probability and random matrices.

Funds available through this grant were exclusively used to provide travel support for US researchers to participate in the ICMP and YRS, with a focus on young researchers. A large number (57) of participants were approved for finanial support, although changes of plans, visa difficulties, and other sources of funding reduced the number of awards paid to travelers to 42, for an average award of slightly over $880 per participant. The healthy turnout was made possible by the proximity of the conference site to the US (ICMP was held for the first time in 35 years in North America). Also, participants generally complemented their support by other sources such as personal or institutional funds. Among the supported participants,

• 25 were undergraduate or graduate students,
• 12 were postdoctoral researchers or other early-stage academics
• 5 were senior researchers with no other travel support through research grants. • 14 were female.

A survey among supported participants was conducted after the conference, in which a large majority of participants rated their overall experience at the ICMP and YRS as ‘excellent’ or ‘very good’. Twenty of the participants presented their own work through talks or posters. Frequently, the high quality and introductory nature of the plenary talks was mentioned, giving the opportunity to learn about new fields and open challenges. Very often, participants also mentioned having informal discussions with other participants, providing an opportunity for networking and exploring potential future research collaborations.

NSF has supported travel to the ICMP on multiple occasions, going back to 1979, most recently in Montr ́eal 2018, Santiago de Chile 2015, Aalborg 2012, Prague 2009, Rio de Janeiro 2006 and Lisbon 2003. These opportunities have had strong impact on the US mathematical physics community and its strong standing among leading research carried out in this field (for example, six of the the sixteen plenary talks at the recent ICMP were given by researchers from US institutions). The PIs would like to express their gratitude for this continued support of the field through NSF.
